objects.author: WSJ Noted.
objects.title: Colleges with Covid-19 Outbreaks are Sending Students Home

tags.label: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

objects.html:
2. Public health experts are worried about the communities students are returning to.

Read More

Colleges Send Students Home as Outbreaks Worsen. Are They Creating a New Coronavirus Threat?

By Melissa Korn

Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said on the “Today” show Wednesday that sending students home after outbreaks is “the worst thing you could do.” He said schools should isolate infected or potentially infected students on campus instead.

A. David Paltiel, a professor at the Yale School of Public Health cautioned against shipping students back into the community, saying: “Just because a kid is asymptomatic doesn’t mean it’s safe to send that kid home. They could be exposed and incubating. They could be in fact a ticking time bomb.”

3. Government officials want students to stay put.

Vice President Mike Pence asked governors to encourage universities in their states to keep students on or near campus when positive tests crop up to minimize potential exposure to the wider community, according to a recording of a call reviewed by the Wall Street Journal. On the same call, White House coronavirus coordinator Dr. Deborah Birx warned that letting asymptomatic students return home could result in similar outbreaks to those seen in parts of the South in June, when young people traveled to popular vacation spots.

Read the original article by Melissa Korn here.
